answer_html: Hence the general solution to is \(\begin{bmatrix}\mathbf{x_{1}}\\ \mathbf{x_{2}}\\ \mathbf{x_{3}}\end{bmatrix} = a\begin{bmatrix}7\\ -4\\1\end{bmatrix}\), where a is any real number.
answer_latex:
Hence the general solution to is
$\begin{bmatrix}\mathbf{x_{1}}\\ \mathbf{x_{2}}\\ \mathbf{x_{3}}\end{bmatrix} = a\begin{bmatrix}7\\
-4\\1\end{bmatrix}$, where a is any real number.
hints_html: The matrix U describes a system of two equations and three unknowns. Hence the homogeneous system has at least one free parameter, and hence infinitely many solutions.
hints_latex:
The matrix \emph{U} describes a system of two equations and three
unknowns. Hence the homogeneous system has at least one free parameter,
and hence infinitely many solutions.
hints_raw: The matrix ''U'' describes a system of two equations and three unknowns. Hence the homogeneous system has at least one free parameter, and hence infinitely many solutions.
question: B 03 (a)
sols_html:
Elementary row operations don’t change the solution of a homogeneous equation, hence the solutions of Ux = 0 also solve Ax = 0.

From the first row on matrix U, we have \(\mathbf{x_{1}} = 7\mathbf{x_{3}}\).

From the second row on matrix U, we have \(\mathbf{x_{2}} = -4\mathbf{x_{3}}\).

Hence the general solution to is \(\begin{bmatrix}\mathbf{x_{1}}\\ \mathbf{x_{2}}\\ \mathbf{x_{3}}\end{bmatrix} = a\begin{bmatrix}7\\ -4\\1\end{bmatrix}\), where a is any real number.
sols_latex:
Elementary row operations don't change the solution of a homogeneous
equation, hence the solutions of \emph{Ux = 0} also solve \emph{Ax = 0}.

From the first row on matrix U, we have
$\mathbf{x_{1}} = 7\mathbf{x_{3}}$.

From the second row on matrix U, we have
$\mathbf{x_{2}} = -4\mathbf{x_{3}}$.

Hence the general solution to is
$\begin{bmatrix}\mathbf{x_{1}}\\ \mathbf{x_{2}}\\ \mathbf{x_{3}}\end{bmatrix} = a\begin{bmatrix}7\\
-4\\1\end{bmatrix}$, where a is any real number.
sols_raw:
Elementary row operations don't change the solution of a homogeneous equation, hence the solutions of ''Ux = 0'' also solve ''Ax = 0''.

From the first row on matrix U, we have <math>\mathbf{x_{1}} = 7\mathbf{x_{3}}</math>.

From the second row on matrix U, we have <math>\mathbf{x_{2}} = -4\mathbf{x_{3}}</math>.

Hence the general solution to is
<math>\begin{bmatrix}\mathbf{x_{1}}\\ \mathbf{x_{2}}\\ \mathbf{x_{3}}\end{bmatrix} = a\begin{bmatrix}7\\
-4\\1\end{bmatrix}</math>, where a is any real number.
statement_html:
Let A be a certain \(2\times 3\) matrix. Suppose that using elementary row operations, the matrix A can be transformed into the matrix

\[\begin{aligned} U = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & -7 \\ 0 & 1 & 4 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

Find all solutions, if any, of the system \(Ax = 0\)
statement_raw:
Let ''A'' be a certain <math>2\times 3 </math> matrix. Suppose that using elementary row operations, the matrix ''A'' can be transformed into the matrix 

:<math>
U = \begin{bmatrix} 
1 & 0 & -7 \\
0 & 1 & 4
\end{bmatrix}
</math>

Find all solutions, if any, of the system <math> Ax = 0 </math>
